title: For all those who don't think the oce skin relates to us
body: Look at the bnz logo, if the southern cross wasn't relavent to us then why would one of the major NZ banks use it as their logo. These people spend vast amounts of money on their image and design, they will have done huge amounts of research and serveys to find an image that represents them as unique to their Region, a lot more than riot would have done for a single skin, and If they came to the conclusion of a southern cross you can be pretty sure they didn't just randomly pick it.

replies.body: so what there are other star constellations view able around the globe. why don't they make it easy and just use a constellation for all regional skins then. it has nothing to do with OCE cultures.

Apart from the southern cross, How does it represent OCE, I don't care ill be buying it because it looks nice, i just don't understand how it relates to OCE, NZ Mauri's AUS Aboriginals AUS and NZ Caucasian settlers, OCE Animals, even the other regions in OCE don't relate, I would have liked to see a nice tribal skin for someone or like a rugby alistar or something, even though i dont care for rugby
Either cosmic kassadin is the oce skin for 1350, or riot said stuff it and decided to do something new

Ahaha why did you use the BNZ logo to prove this point? Not the fact that the Southern Cross is on flags of the 3 biggest countries in Oceania and can be seen from every country in Oceania (to my knowledge). Strangely though in a few 1000 years you wont be able to see the Southern Cross from Oceania at all any more.

Because the flags didn't have hundreds of thousands of dollars spent in the design and research process,
And also In 1000 years is unlikely that any kiwis will still exist but that doesn't stop the community putting them forward as an option for the skin.

That's extremely biased, surely you understand this. BNZ did not attempt to try and represent all of Oceania with their logo, but they happened to decide that Southern Cross would be the best for their purpose. It's like saying the Westpac logo represents all of Oceania as well.

Governments do take flags very seriously, New Zealand is currently in the process of changing it's flag. This is supposedly going to cost NZ $26 million, sited [here](http://www.dpmc.govt.nz/sites/all/files/publications/nzflag-process-cabinet-paper-october2014.pdf). I'd be surprised if BNZ invested this much into a logo.

No they didn't try to represent oceania but they tried to find a logo specific to their particular geographic and cultural location, westpac uses the first letter of its name as a logo, so its a little different.

They do (except for NZ it seems), but remember that when these flags were first made things were a little different, budgets were tighter, both countries were part of the British empire and so the flags were tailored for that purpose and so don't perfectly represent our countries anyway (which is the whole issue behind the flag change in the first place) 

also in regards to the flag change, to prove that governments don't take it too seriously, there isn't a single designer on the flag committee at all, not one. which seems a poor decision when deciding on the design of a flag to represent the entire nation for many many generations to come. Also if they listened to the population, 62% of Kiwis don't want the flag changed in the first place. 
they throw money pointlessly at it for no good reason, and to be perfectly honest all the flag designs they want us to chose from are complete shit anyway, so money well spent i guess....

Using BNZ as an example is still biased, they don't even have a branch in Australia. How can the logo of a B-class bank, supposedly justify the use of the Southern Cross to represent OCE.

> there isn't a single designer on the flag committee at all

A flag for the people should be designed by the people. You said it yourself earlier, the problem with our first flag was that it was designed with political ties in mind.

Im not saying that, I'm saying (badly it seems) that you wouldn't find a bank or other establishment in america or russia etc. that uses the southern cross, where you do find that down here. Likewise we wouldn't use an eagle in our bank logos, hence meaning that the southern cross must have some significance to our neck of the woods but not other regions.

There are many 'people' in NZ some of them happen to be designers and those people are more qualified to select final candidates for the flags, in the end the flag has to be designed by someone, it can either be a NZ citizen that is 8 years old or it can be a NZ citizen who has has 20 years of experience designing things. pretty simple choice to me. The sky tower was built for the people by the people, but they happened to be qualified people. Why should the flag be any different?

Also i never said that was a problem. I said that was the issue behind it, i like the flag just how it is, political ties were mostly what formed our nation and we shouldn't be so quick to forget that.

Nobody said anything about the Southern Cross not representing Oceania. That part everyone understands. Everyone is mad at the fact that A) it took more than two years to create and B) that it represents little to nothing of what Oceania is.

Actually quite a few people I saw making comments about how they don't think it represents us at all because it can be seen from places other than Oceania 
I just  wanted to show them that this isn't a last ditch effort from riot, it does actually represent oce quite well
